definition: Organizational, policy-based, and procedural security measures implemented to manage selection, development, implementation, and maintenance of information security controls protecting customer information, establish governance framework, manage personnel security, and ensure consistent execution of security program across organization. One of three mandatory safeguard categories under GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 3.
official_description: Administrative safeguards represent management-level and operational controls forming organizational foundation of information security program. Per 16 CFR 314.4(c), administrative safeguards must include: (1) security policies and procedures addressing all GLBA requirements, information security standards and baselines; (2) access control policies implementing need-to-know and least privilege principles; (3) personnel security including background checks, separation of duties, role definitions; (4) security awareness training for all personnel; (5) incident response procedures; (6) change management processes; (7) configuration management and security baseline enforcement; (8) vulnerability management procedures; (9) vendor and third-party risk management; (10) audit and monitoring procedures; (11) business continuity and disaster recovery planning; (12) documentation and recordkeeping. Administrative safeguards establish organizational commitment, governance structure, policies, procedures, roles/responsibilities enabling effective technical and physical safeguards. Weakness in administrative safeguards undermines entire security program. Administrative controls documented in writing, communicated to personnel, enforced consistently, updated regularly based on risk assessment and testing results.
applicable_to: All financial institutions under GLBA; all organizational levels from board to frontline staff; all departments and business units; applies to employees, contractors, vendors, third-party service providers; all locations and operations; applies regardless of institution size or complexity (scalable implementation)

definition: Technology-based security controls, mechanisms, and systems implemented to protect customer information systems, data, networks, applications, and infrastructure from unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, disruption, or destruction. Includes encryption, multi-factor authentication, system hardening, intrusion detection, monitoring. One of three mandatory safeguard categories under GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 3.
official_description: Technical safeguards represent technology controls protecting information systems and data. Per 16 CFR 314.4(c) and 314.4(d), technical safeguards must include: (1) encryption of customer information at rest (AES-256 minimum for databases, backups, archives, removable media) and in transit (TLS 1.2+ for network communications, email, web, APIs); (2) multi-factor authentication (MFA) for system access, especially remote access and privileged accounts; (3) network security controls including firewalls, network segmentation, intrusion detection/prevention systems; (4) access control systems and technologies implementing authentication, authorization, account management, session management; (5) system hardening using secure configurations, CIS benchmarks or equivalent, removal of unnecessary services; (6) endpoint protection (antivirus, malware detection, endpoint detection and response); (7) vulnerability management including vulnerability scanning, patch management, prioritization; (8) secure software development practices including code review, application security testing; (9) audit logging and monitoring systems (SIEM); (10) data loss prevention (DLP) technologies; (11) email and threat protection; (12) database security controls; (13) testing through vulnerability assessments and penetration testing. Technical safeguards must be continuously monitored, tested, and updated to address evolving threats.

definition: Physical and environmental security controls implemented to protect facilities, equipment, media, infrastructure, and physical access points containing or providing access to customer information and information systems. Addresses facility access, environmental protection, media security, secure disposal. One of three mandatory safeguard categories under GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 3.
official_description: Physical safeguards protect physical premises, buildings, equipment, storage media, and infrastructure containing customer information. Per 16 CFR 314.4(c), physical safeguards must include: (1) facility access controls including badge/card access systems, biometric controls, visitor management, escort requirements, access logs; (2) perimeter security such as fencing, gates, security guards, surveillance, lighting; (3) visitor management procedures with sign-in, badge issuance, restrictions, escorts; (4) environmental controls for fire suppression, temperature/humidity monitoring and control, water detection, power protection with UPS and backup generators; (5) media protection with secure storage for backup media, locked cabinets, offsite storage, chain of custody; (6) secure media disposal including hard drive destruction, degaussing, certified media destruction, document shredding; (7) equipment security with inventory tracking, cable locks for portable devices, secure disposal; (8) workstation and mobile device security with clean desk policies, screen locks, privacy screens, encryption; (9) data center and server room security with restricted access, environmental monitoring, redundancy; (10) regular physical security assessments and testing. Physical safeguards address geographic location risks, facility damage risks, unauthorized physical access risks, and environmental hazards.
